prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Mrs. Honeychurch: Practical and opinionated, speaking with a mix of motherly authority and exasperation, deeply concerned with social appearances.
The Maid: Efficient and unassuming, speaking in short, practical sentences, rarely offering personal thoughts or opinions.
Cecil: Arrogant and affected, speaking in an overly refined and ironic manner, viewing the world through the lens of superiority and aesthetics.
Freddy: Energetic and mischievous, speaking in a playful and teasing manner, unafraid to challenge social conventions with humor.
Mr. Beebe: A witty and observant clergyman, speaking with dry humor and insight, balancing kindness with a touch of cynicism.


Dialogue History: Mrs. Honeychurch: I hope you gave a careful answer, dear.
Freddy: I answered 'No' There! Fly into a stew! I can't help it--had to say it. I had to say no. He ought never to have asked me.
Mrs. Honeychurch: Ridiculous child! You think you're so holy and truthful, but really it's only abominable conceit. Do you suppose that a man like Cecil would take the slightest notice of anything you say? I hope he boxed your ears. How dare you say no?
Freddy: Oh, do keep quiet, mother! I had to say no when I couldn't say yes. I tried to laugh as if I didn't mean what I said, and, as Cecil laughed too, and went away, it may be all right. But I feel my foot's in it. Oh, do keep quiet, though, and let a man do some work.
Mrs. Honeychurch: No, I shall not keep quiet. You know all that has passed between them in Rome; you know why he is down here, and yet you deliberately insult him, and try to turn him out of my house.
Freddy: Not a bit! I only let out I didn't like him. I don't hate him, but I don't like him. What I mind is that he'll tell Lucy.
Mrs. Honeychurch: Well, I like him, I know his mother; he's good, he's clever, he's rich, he's well connected--Oh, you needn't kick the piano! He's well connected--I'll say it again if you like: he's well connected.
Mrs. Honeychurch: And he has beautiful manners.
Freddy: I liked him till just now. I suppose it's having him spoiling Lucy's first week at home; and it's also something that Mr. Beebe said, not knowing.
Mrs. Honeychurch: Mr. Beebe? I don't see how Mr. Beebe comes in.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Freddy: You know Mr. Beebe's funny way, when you never quite know what he means. He said:

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Lucy: Intelligent but uncertain, speaking with curiosity and a growing sense of self-awareness, torn between duty and passion.
Mr. Vyse: Coldly intellectual and detached, speaking in precise, measured tones, valuing logic over emotion.


Dialogue History: Mr. Vyse: But I love you, and I did think you loved me!
Lucy: I did not, I thought I did at first. I am sorry, and ought to have refused you this last time, too.
Mr. Vyse: You don't love me, evidently. I dare say you are right not to. But it would hurt a little less if I knew why.
Lucy: Because
Lucy: you're the sort who can't know any one intimately.
Lucy: I don't mean exactly that. But you will question me, though I beg you not to, and I must say something. It is that, more or less. When we were only acquaintances, you let me be myself, but now you're always protecting me. I won't be protected. I will choose for myself what is ladylike and right. To shield me is an insult. Can't I be trusted to face the truth but I must get it second-hand through you? A woman's place! You despise my mother--I know you do--because she's conventional and bothers over puddings; but, oh goodness! conventional, Cecil, you're that, for you may understand beautiful things, but you don't know how to use them; and you wrap yourself up in art and books and music, and would try to wrap up me. I won't be stifled, not by the most glorious music, for people are more glorious, and you hide them from me. That's why I break off my engagement. You were all right as long as you kept to things, but when you came to people--
Mr. Vyse: It is true.
Lucy: True on the whole,
Mr. Vyse: True, every word. It is a revelation. It is--I.
Lucy: Anyhow, those are my reasons for not being your wife.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Mr. Vyse: It is true. I fell to pieces the very first day we were engaged. I behaved like a cad to Beebe and to your brother. You are even greater than I thought. I'm not going to worry you. You are far too good to me. I shall never forget your insight; and, dear, I only blame you for this: you might have warned me in the early stages, before you felt you wouldn't marry me, and so have given me a chance to improve. I have never known you till this evening. I have just used you as a peg for my silly notions of what a woman should be. But this evening you are a different person: new thoughts--even a new voice--

Minnie Beebe: Cheerful and inquisitive, speaking with youthful enthusiasm, eager to be involved in everything around her.
Mr. Vyse: Coldly intellectual and detached, speaking in precise, measured tones, valuing logic over emotion.
Miss Bartlett: Anxious and self-sacrificing, speaking in a flustered and overly proper manner, constantly worried about social decorum.

Freddy: Energetic and mischievous, speaking in a playful and teasing manner, unafraid to challenge social conventions with humor.
Mr. Beebe: A witty and observant clergyman, speaking with dry humor and insight, balancing kindness with a touch of cynicism.


Dialogue History: Mr. Beebe: Miss Honeychurch!
Lucy: Yes.
Mr. Beebe: I met them on the hill. Your brother told me.
Lucy: Oh he did?
Mr. Beebe: I needn't say that it will go no further.
Lucy: Mother, Charlotte, Cecil, Freddy, you,
Mr. Beebe: If you'll let me say so, I am very glad, and I am certain that you have done the right thing.
Lucy: So I hoped other people would think, but they don't seem to.
Mr. Beebe: I could see that Miss Bartlett thought it unwise.
Lucy: So does mother. Mother minds dreadfully.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Mr. Beebe: I am very sorry for that,

Mrs. Honeychurch: Lucy, is anything the matter with Cecil?
Lucy: No, I don't think so, mother; Cecil's all right.
Mrs. Honeychurch: Perhaps he's tired.

[INST] Character Info: Miss Catherine Alan: Kind-hearted and conventional, speaking in a gentle and somewhat naive manner, content with the status quo.
Lucy: Intelligent but uncertain, speaking with curiosity and a growing sense of self-awareness, torn between duty and passion.
The Chambermaid: Practical and observant, speaking with a touch of sarcasm, quick to notice the affairs of those she serves.
The Vicar: Proper and somewhat stiff, speaking in a formal and moralizing manner, concerned with propriety and religious duty.
Mr. Beebe: A witty and observant clergyman, speaking with dry humor and insight, balancing kindness with a touch of cynicism.


Dialogue History: Mr. Beebe: Miss Lavish has led your cousin astray. She hopes to find the true Italy in the wet I believe.
Lucy: Miss Lavish is so original,
Lucy: Is it true, that Miss Lavish is writing a book?
Mr. Beebe: They do say so.
Lucy: What is it about?
Mr. Beebe: It will be a novel, dealing with modern Italy. Let me refer you for an account to Miss Catharine Alan, who uses words herself more admirably than any one I know.
Lucy: I wish Miss Lavish would tell me herself. We started such friends. But I don't think she ought to have run away with Baedeker that morning in Santa Croce. Charlotte was most annoyed at finding me practically alone, and so I couldn't help being a little annoyed with Miss Lavish.
Mr. Beebe: The two ladies, at all events, have made it up.
Miss Catherine Alan: Oh, dear Miss Honeychurch, you will catch a chill! And Mr. Beebe here besides. Who would suppose this is Italy? There is my sister actually nursing the hot-water can; no comforts or proper provisions.
Miss Catherine Alan: I could hear your beautiful playing, Miss Honeychurch, though I was in my room with the door shut. Doors shut; indeed, most necessary. No one has the least idea of privacy in this country. And one person catches it from another.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The Chambermaid: Fa niente, sono vecchia.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Rev. Cuthbert Eager: Self-important and patronizing, speaking with an air of superiority, convinced of his own cultural and moral wisdom.
Italian Lady: Warm and expressive, speaking with animated gestures, quick to offer hospitality and passionate opinions.
Lucy: Intelligent but uncertain, speaking with curiosity and a growing sense of self-awareness, torn between duty and passion.
Mr. Emerson: Passionate and unconventional, speaking in a forthright and philosophical manner, unafraid to challenge societal norms.
George Emerson: Introspective and brooding, speaking in thoughtful, measured tones, often struggling to articulate his deep emotions.
Miss Lavish: Dramatic and self-important, speaking in elaborate and flamboyant language, convinced of her own literary genius.


Dialogue History: Lucy: Oh, please--! If my father was alive, I am sure he would vote Radical again now that Ireland is all right. And as it is, the glass over our front door was broken last election, and Freddy is sure it was the Tories; but mother says nonsense, a tramp.
Miss Lavish: Shameful! A manufacturing district, I suppose?
Lucy: No--in the Surrey hills. About five miles from Dorking, looking over the Weald.
Miss Lavish: What a delightful part; I know it so well. It is full of the very nicest people. Do you know Sir Harry Otway--a Radical if ever there was?
Lucy: Very well indeed.
Miss Lavish: And old Mrs. Butterworth the philanthropist?
Lucy: Why, she rents a field of us! How funny!
Miss Lavish: Oh, you have property in Surrey?
Lucy: Hardly any, Only thirty acres--just the garden, all downhill, and some fields.
Miss Lavish: Bless us! Bless us and save us! We've lost the way.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Miss Lavish: Lost! lost! My dear Miss Lucy, during our political diatribes we have taken a wrong turning. How those horrid Conservatives would jeer at us! What are we to do? Two lone females in an unknown town. Now, this is what I call an adventure.

Dialogue History: George Emerson: Because we think it improves our characters. But he is kind to people because he loves them; and they find him out, and are offended, or frightened.
Lucy: How silly of them! I think that a kind action done tactfully--
George Emerson: Tact!
George Emerson: Were you snubbed?
Mr. Emerson: But we have spoilt the pleasure of I don't know how many people. They won't come back.
Rev. Cuthbert Eager: ...full of innate sympathy...quickness to perceive good in others...vision of the brotherhood of man...
Mr. Emerson: Don't let us spoil yours, Have you looked at those saints?
Lucy: Yes, They are lovely. Do you know which is the tombstone that is praised in Ruskin?
Mr. Emerson: Why will he look at that fresco? I saw nothing in it.
Lucy: I like Giotto, It is so wonderful what they say about his tactile values. Though I like things like the Della Robbia babies better.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Mr. Emerson: So you ought. A baby is worth a dozen saints. And my baby's worth the whole of Paradise, and as far as I can see he lives in Hell.

[INST] Character Info: Mrs. Honeychurch: Practical and opinionated, speaking with a mix of motherly authority and exasperation, deeply concerned with social appearances.
Lucy: Intelligent but uncertain, speaking with curiosity and a growing sense of self-awareness, torn between duty and passion.
Cecil: Arrogant and affected, speaking in an overly refined and ironic manner, viewing the world through the lens of superiority and aesthetics.
Freddy: Energetic and mischievous, speaking in a playful and teasing manner, unafraid to challenge social conventions with humor.
Mr. Beebe: A witty and observant clergyman, speaking with dry humor and insight, balancing kindness with a touch of cynicism.


Dialogue History: Freddy: Friends of Cecil's,
Lucy: But Cecil's Emersons--they can't possibly be the same ones--there is that--
Mr. Beebe: The Emersons who were at Florence, do you mean? No, I don't suppose it will prove to be them. It is probably a long cry from them to friends of Mr. Vyse's. Oh, Mrs. Honeychurch, the oddest people! The queerest people! For our part we liked them, didn't we?
Mr. Beebe: There was a great scene over some violets. They picked violets and filled all the vases in the room of these very Miss Alans who have failed to come to Cissie Villa. Poor little ladies! So shocked and so pleased. It used to be one of Miss Catharine's great stories. it began. They found the whole room a mass of blue--vases and jugs--and the story ends with It is all very difficult. Yes, I always connect those Florentine Emersons with violets.
Freddy: Fiasco's done you this time,
Mr. Beebe: These particular Emersons consisted of a father and a son--the son a goodly, if not a good young man; not a fool, I fancy, but very immature--pessimism, et cetera. Our special joy was the father--such a sentimental darling, and people declared he had murdered his wife.
Mrs. Honeychurch: Murdered his wife? Lucy, don't desert us--go on playing bumble-puppy. Really, the Pension Bertolini must have been the oddest place. That's the second murderer I've heard of as being there. Whatever was Charlotte doing to stop? By-the-by, we really must ask Charlotte here some time.
Freddy: Oh, don't go!
Lucy: I must go, Don't be silly. You always overdo it when you play.
Mrs. Honeychurch: Harris!

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]

Dialogue History: Lucy: What would you ask us?
Miss Lavish: There goes my local-colour box! I must have a word with him!
Mr. Emerson: Hateful bishop! Hard in life, hard in death. Go out into the sunshine, little boy, and kiss your hand to the sun, for that is where you ought to be. Intolerable bishop!
Mr. Emerson: Look at him! Here's a mess: a baby hurt, cold, and frightened! But what else can you expect from a church?
Mr. Emerson: You are a clever woman, You have done more than all the relics in the world. I am not of your creed, but I do believe in those who make their fellow-creatures happy. There is no scheme of the universe--
Italian Lady: Niente,
Lucy: I'm not sure she understands English,
Mr. Emerson: That woman understands everything, But what are you doing here? Are you doing the church? Are you through with the church?
Lucy: No, I came here with Miss Lavish, who was to explain everything; and just by the door--it is too bad!--she simply ran away, and after waiting quite a time, I had to come in by myself.
Mr. Emerson: Why shouldn't you?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: George Emerson: Yes, why shouldn't you come by yourself?
